message.content:
selective attention
divided attention
spatial attention
sustained attention
covert attention
overt attention
endogenous attention
exogenous attention
joint attention
attention restoration.

(Note: These terms are commonly used in psychology and cognitive science to describe different types and aspects of visual attention. A brief description of each term follows:

* Selective attention refers to the ability to focus on one or a few relevant stimuli while ignoring irrelevant ones.
* Divided attention involves processing multiple stimuli or tasks simultaneously.
* Spatial attention refers to the allocation of attention to different locations in space.
* Sustained attention is the ability to maintain focus on a task or stimulus over a prolonged period.
* Covert attention refers to directing attention to a location or object without eye movements.
* Overt attention involves shifting the gaze or head to attend to a stimulus.
* Endogenous attention is voluntary and goal-directed, while exogenous attention is stimulus-driven and involuntary.
* Joint attention refers to the shared focus of two or more individuals on an object or event.
* Attention restoration refers to the recovery of attentional resources after a period of mental fatigue or depletion.)
